ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: How to engage with pre-modern and modern literature, put texts in conversation with one another.
Close reading of literary texts. Expression thereof in short papers.
This course greatly helped me to develop my critical thinking skills, close reading, and articulation of thoughts in a productive and nuanced manner.
I grew as a writer by taking this course. Professor Levin encouraged us to focus on close-read in our essays, and I learned to examine how authors use punctuation to convey meaning.
I learned to critically analyze texts and dive deeper into the elements of a written work
I developed my close reading abilities for literature texts more than in my first semester of Directed Studies literature.

Especially in this semester, coming with a fair amount of background already, a major skill I developed was making connections between texts. You very soon to start to realize that while the canon is fabulously diverse, there are some core conflicts and themes that everyone seems to deal with.
Writing skills, reading skills

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The seminar format was extremely helpful in fostering productive conversation.

All DS classes move very quickly. This allows for excellent breadth with some sacrifice in depth. The pace can also be stressful, and the removal of Madam Bovary from the syllabus was a relief. I suggest making the shorter syllabus (or some version of a shorter syllabus) permanent.
I loved this class!  We learned to explore a variety of texts throughout time and place them in dialogue with one another.  The course showed me the value to close reading.

I think that the course picked up as we went along, but I found the quality of discussion for the first few texts slightly lacking. This may have simply been a drawback of the length and scope of Hamlet and Don Quixote, but I was somewhat disappointed by how little I felt we delved into those works. However, I thought that the quality of our discussions was very good overall.

Professor Levin is an excellent instructor. She lets students guide the discussion and really makes an effort to hear what everyone has to say. She also gave extensive feedback on essays. The only weakness was that the nature of conversation meant that some parts of books were covered in-depth whereas others seemed almost neglected entirely; but this is perhaps an inevitability in DS.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The small seminar format was crucial for me to enjoy this class!
Virtual seminars were smooth and satisfying. I appreciated my professor's initial effort to keep microphones unmuted.

The seminar discussion format was very well equipped for Zoom.  I was lucky enough to have an enriching academic experience filled with amazing books and even better insight from peers in this virtual year.
As much as I hate to say it, turning off the zoom chat was a good move.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: There might be more specialized literature classes that might be better. Otherwise, this is a pretty good survey of more recent texts.
Yes. I was unsure about DS after the fall semester but I'm glad that I continued in the spring.

I would highly recommend this course to another student! Both Professor Levin and the books we read each week made this course my favourite to attend each week. It was both a joy to attend and an intellectual challenge.

Yes!  Directed Studies is intense but it develops so much of your writing skills.  The coursework and seminars will leave you a much stronger thinker and effective communicator.  I've gained a greater appreciation for close reading and literary analysis.

I would recommend this course to any student who is seriously interested in the humanities or the study of literature. We developed an understanding of the trend of literary influence from Ancient Greece to the modern day, which is certainly not easy to do, or to achieve with a course that is not specifically directed towards it.

Yes. From Milton to Shakepeare to Woolf the syllabus is absolutely fantastic; unlike in other DS courses where you feel like your reading parts of sections and getting fragments of a theorist's ideas, we read most of Lit books cover-to-cover. The experience is satisfying.
If you want to read really good books and get an overview of modern literature this is a good course for that.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: None.
recorded lecture
Along with having twice weekly seminars, the course had required reading each week.
Seminars paired with a weekly lecture
In addition to the biweekly seminars there was a recorded lecture for the entirety of the DS program.
Lecture released at the beginning of the week and then discussion sections
